questions.text: A patient involved in an automobile accident presents with a sharp object puncture of the middle of the sternum at about the level of the 4th or 5th costal cartilage. If the object also penetrated pericardium and heart wall, which heart chamber would most likely be damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Remember, the anterior surface, or sternocostal surface, of the heart is mostly made up of the right ventricle. So, if an object punctured the sternum, it would be likely to pierce the right ventricle.

questions.text: If the ductus arteriosus does not spontaneously close off soon after birth (to become the ligamentum arteriosum), it may have to be surgically ligated. When clamping or ligating it, what important structure immediately behind it must be identified and saved?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The ductus arteriosus, located between the pulmonary artery and the aortic arch, becomes the ligamentum arteriosum after birth
  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve loops under the arch of the aorta, passing immediately posterior to the ligamentum arteriosum, making it vulnerable during PDA ligation
  • Damage to this nerve can cause hoarseness due to vocal cord paralysis
  • Arch of the azygos vein lies on the right side, over the right bronchus (Option A ruled out)
  • Internal thoracic artery descends along the anterior thoracic wall, far from the ductus (Option B ruled out)
  • Left phrenic nerve passes anterior to the lung root, not behind the ductus (Option C ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The left recurrent laryngeal nerve runs posterior to the ligamentum arteriosum
  • It is the key structure to identify and preserve during PDA surgery
  • Injury leads to hoarseness from vocal cord paralysis

questions.text: An elderly lady suffers a coronary occlusion and subsequently it is noted that there is a complete heart block (that is, the right and left bundles of the conduction system have been damaged). The artery most likely involved is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The anterior interventricular artery (LAD) supplies the anterior 2/3 of the interventricular septum, which houses the right and left bundle branches
  • Occlusion of the LAD can therefore lead to bundle branch blocks or complete heart block due to damage to the intraventricular conduction pathways
  • Option A: Acute marginal branch - supplies the right ventricular wall, not the interventricular septum (Option A ruled out)
  • Option B: Circumflex branch - primarily supplies the left atrium and lateral wall of the left ventricle, not the interventricular septum (Option B ruled out)
  • Option D: Obtuse marginal - branch of the circumflex, supplies lateral LV wall, not the conduction system (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • LAD artery is the main supply to the bundle branches via the interventricular septum
  • Complete heart block following MI strongly suggests LAD occlusion
  • Knowing vascular supply of the cardiac conduction system is crucial for clinical correlation

choices.text: Functional closure occurs due to fibrous tissue growth at 1 year of age
Anatomical closure occurs immediately at birth due to pressure reversal
Functional closure occurs at birth due to left atrial pressure exceeding right atrial pressure
Anatomical closure is complete by birth in 100% of individuals

questions.text: In normal postnatal development, the closure of the foramen ovale occurs in two stages. Which of the following correctly describes the nature and timing of these closures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Functional closure of the foramen ovale happens at birth due to the rise in left atrial pressure (as pulmonary circulation opens) and fall in right atrial pressure → causes septum primum to press against septum secundum
  • Anatomical closure occurs later, typically by 1 year of age, as tissue fusion completes
  • Option A is incorrect as anatomical (not functional) closure occurs via tissue growth (Option A ruled out)
  • Option B reverses the timing - anatomical closure is not immediate at birth (Option B ruled out)
  • Option D is incorrect - up to 25-30% of adults may retain a probe-patent foramen ovale (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Functional closure of the foramen ovale occurs at birth, driven by pressure changes
  • Anatomical closure happens over weeks to months and is not universal
  • A patent foramen ovale may persist in a significant number of adults

questions.text: Blockage of blood flow in the proximal part of the anterior interventricular artery could deprive a large area of heart tissue of blood supply, unless a substantial retrograde flow into this artery develops via an important anastomosis with which other artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Traumatic aortic injury commonly occurs at the aortic isthmus, where the mobile arch meets the fixed descending thoracic aorta
  • This region lies just distal to the left subclavian artery and is held in place by the ligamentum arteriosum, making it vulnerable to shear forces during rapid deceleration
  • In the image, Label C corresponds to this anatomical transition zone

Explanation of other options:

Option A: D - Located further down the descending thoracic aorta, not the common rupture point (Option A ruled out)

Option C: B - Represents the ascending aorta, which is more mobile and rarely ruptured in isolation (Option C ruled out)

Option D: A -Corresponds to the aortic arch, not the junctional zone where the mobile and fixed parts meet (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The aortic isthmus is the most common site of traumatic aortic rupture
  • It lies just distal to the left subclavian artery, near the ligamentum arteriosum
  • Recognition of this location is vital in blunt chest trauma assessment.

questions.text: Which structure does NOT lie in the coronary sulcus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The coronary sulcus (also called the atrioventricular groove) separates the atria from the ventricles and contains key vessels that run around the heart horizontally
  • The following structures lie in the coronary sulcus:
    • Circumflex artery - branch of the left coronary artery that runs in the left part of the coronary sulcus (Option A ruled out)
    • Coronary sinus - the main venous drainage of the heart, lies in the posterior coronary sulcus (Option B ruled out)
    • Right coronary artery (RCA) - courses in the right part of the coronary sulcus (Option C ruled out)
  • The right marginal artery, however, branches off from the RCA and descends along the right margin of the heart, not in the coronary sulcus (Correct)

Key Takeaways:

  • Coronary sulcus houses major horizontal vessels like the RCA, circumflex artery, and coronary sinus
  • Right marginal artery travels along the inferior border of the heart, outside the sulcus
  • Recognizing the pathways of coronary vessels helps in both imaging and surgery

questions.text: While attempting to suture the distal end of a coronary bypass onto the anterior interventricular artery, the surgeon accidentally passed the needle through the vein shown in the image below. Which vein was damaged?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The great cardiac vein runs in the anterior interventricular sulcus, accompanying the LAD (anterior interventricular) artery
  • During coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the LAD artery is a common target; the adjacent great cardiac vein is at risk of accidental injury
  • Artery–vein pairs to remember:
    • LAD artery - Great cardiac vein
    • Posterior interventricular artery (PDA) - Middle cardiac vein
    • Right marginal artery - Small cardiac vein
    • Circumflex artery - Great cardiac vein (in coronary sulcus)

Explanation of other options:

Option A: A is pointing to the right ventricle - a chamber, not a vein (Option A ruled out)

Option C: C is the LAD artery itself - an artery, not a vein (Option C ruled out)

Option D: D is near the left atrium/pulmonary veins - not adjacent to the LAD artery (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • The great cardiac vein is the venous counterpart to the LAD artery
  • In bypass grafting to the LAD, always identify and protect the great cardiac vein
  • Mastering artery-vein relationships in the heart is crucial for both clinical and surgical anatomy.

questions.text: In obstruction of the superior or inferior vena cava, venous blood is returned to the heart by an alternate route via the azygos vein, which becomes dilated in the process. Which of the following structures might it compress as a result?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the image, label A corresponds to the esophagus, which lies immediately anterior to the azygos vein
  • In SVC or IVC obstruction, blood is rerouted via the azygos system, leading to azygos vein dilation
  • This dilated azygos vein, lying posterior to the esophagus, can cause esophageal compression.
  • Label B corresponds to intercostal veins draining into the azygos system, not subject to compression (Option B ruled out)
  • Label C is the arch of the azygos vein, which is superior and arches over the right main bronchus-not typically compressed itself (Option C ruled out)
  • Label D is likely a segmental artery or vein, not anatomically positioned to be compressed by the azygos (Option D ruled out)

Key Takeaways:

  • Azygos vein dilatation can cause esophageal compression
  • The esophagus lies anterior to the azygos vein
  • Collateral circulation via the azygos system is important in SVC/IVC obstruction
